story:
The CFT: Your Hub for Tattoo Education

The Center for Tattoo History and Culture is a new, not-for-profit foundation that operates outside of traditional academic channels. Our team consists of an ever-growing group of passionate people who believe that we can rethink how academic and archival tattoo-related content is made available to anyone interested in doing deeper research. We come from a wide variety of backgrounds: anthropology, archaeology, art history, history, library science, philosophy, popular culture studies, the tattoo industry, and more. We're admittedly nerdy, and we care deeply about making sure that tattoo myths are not perpetuated and that quality content about tattoo history and culture is readily accessible.

Tattooing has experienced unprecedented global popularity in the 21st century. Ever more people have been interested in studying tattooing in a formal way. But expert knowledge can be hard to find. Resources are currently scattered across libraries and museums, hidden away in private collections, randomly spread across numerous internet archives. This has left large gaps in the corpus of scholarly resources and caused people seeking tattoo knowledge to fend for themselves, often relying upon erroneous secondary sources that perpetuate myth, treat folklore as fact, or promote theories based on outdated concepts.

The CFT will be a virtual “center”—a digital hub with a variety of public-facing informational services and a subscription-based* area for those doing more intensive research. This way, we can reach far more people in a much easier way than the current mess of having to visit never-ending numbers of websites, pay for (often exorbitant) access to traditional academic journals, vainly google-search for that article you loved that you read 5 years ago but which now seems to have disappeared, endlessly scroll through an Instagram feed to try to find an image you remember was maybe posted by a certain person...Phew. Sound familiar? We have solutions for you!

Beyond our digital platform, we also seek to create a research- and archives-based tattoo community. As advisory board member, Kimberly Baltzer-Jaray, mentions in the video above: the CFT “can bring together amateurs and scholars from across the globe: so philosophers like myself...anthropologists, sociologists, psychologists, fine arts majors, everyday people, anyone, everyone who's interested in anything to do with tattooing.”

Please read about our many planned projects on our website: https://centerfortattoo.org/projects/

*Our subscription-based area will always be free for students and low-income researchers who can provide appropriate documentation.

Why does the Center for Tattoo History and Culture need funding?

All of the CFT's resources will be available digital-humanities style through a website-based interface. Since our mission is an educational one, not a profit-making one, we will be incorporating as a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. Not having a brick-and-mortar location saves us a lot in overhead!

1) We have so much amazing information and so many resources to share, but we need to create the proper digital platform. A large part of our campaign will let us hire a web development team that can create a site that has both a content-rich public face and an even content-richer subscription service that hosts text-, image-, and ultimately video-intensive databases. We’ll also be hosting discussion forums and ways for enthusiasts to help volunteer for the project à la citizen-scientist initiatives. This will be an expensive website to build—not a DIY Wordpress project, as much as many of us involved with the CFT love dabbling in web development. With our $30,000 campaign successfully funded, we will be able to build phase one of the website: a set of public-facing informational pages, a structure for starting in on our database projects, and a subscription interface. With our stretch goal met (see below), we can build the entire site that we have envisioned.

2) Setting up a foundation as a properly accredited 501(c)3 takes proper professional help. We’d like to hire a legal team (hopefully at discounted rates) to make sure all our t’s are crossed and our i’s dotted so that we’re serving the public good correctly and that we’ll be well-positioned to raise additional money through government and private-foundation grants. We also want to hire an accounting team to make sure that all funds are allocated responsibly. As a 501(c)3, all of the legal and financial side of things will be transparent.

3) Quality content requires fees that range from licensing arrangements to paying people to share their intellectual property. We are tired of so many content mills that refuse to pay contributors (hmmmmm…perhaps that's why there are so many problems with tattoo-related content out there on the internet?). The foundation deeply believes in paying contributors to the project for their work and so the last part of the initial goal will be to begin compensating CFT writers and researchers to upload quality content to the website.

We’d like to add a stretch goal beyond the initial $30,000 that comprises an additional $30,000. This will enable the CFT to build the entire website we envision complete with discussion forums, e-commerce, and citizen-scientist capacity, and upload even more content while awaiting successful grant applications and fund disbursement.

If we don’t meet our funding goal, it just means it might take us longer to implement the first phase of the foundation project—we’ll focus on getting all of our paperwork in order and phase in the web development and content uploading over a longer time frame. But we have a feeling that there are many of you out there with an equal passion for tattoo history and culture who would like to see our vision become a reality. Let’s get the CFT funded!

The Perks

We’re offering a range of perks to fit a variety of budgets and levels of interest in researching tattoos. See the perk list for our complete offerings, but here are some highlights:

For those of you who anticipate researching tattooing on a regular basis over several years and paying to use our comprehensive text-, image-, and oral-history databases, we have two particularly value-minded perks:

•A lifetime behind-the-paywall subscription for a donation of $200—the price of a small tattoo! We’ll be starting the subscription service at an annual fee of $25, and as we continue to add more content, the annual price will go up. With successful funding, we hope to have the subscription area of the website ready by this time next year.

•A 2-years-for-the-price-of-1 subscription for a donation of $25—you can even select what year you’d like this to begin. (For example, if you are a student now, and thus subject to a free annual subscription, you can elect to redeem your subscription once you’re done with school.)

For those of you who have a more casual interest in tattoo history and culture and will be primarily using our public-facing content such as our blog and our referral service, we have many ways you can help crowdfund the foundation from standard t-shirts and stickers to more unique items:

•A set of temporary tattoos for a donation of $20—the CFT logo plus 7 other designs hand-chosen by our advisory board members to reflect their research. These motifs will help you travel across the world and through time.

•A $5 “the CFT is awesome” donation for those of you who are looking forward to having the public-facing part of the CFT to browse or for those of you frustrated by academia and excited to see a scholarly project being created outside the walls of the ivory tower. Of course, you are welcome to contribute much more...

Other Ways You Can Help

We invite you to visit our website for even more information about the CFT than we could reasonably describe here. Follow us on social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) for regular updates. Sign up for our mailing list.

And please, even if you can't contribute, help spread the word! Post our campaign on your social media, email friends you think might be interested, use the Indiegogo share tools!

We thank you for your support.

 

We'd also like to thank our video team and image providers:

Video editing and animation by David Huettner: www.dchue.com; soundtrack by Jefferson Friedman

The Center for Tattoo History and Culture would like to thank the following individuals and institutions for letting us use their images in this crowdfunding video. Be sure to seek out their services if their visuals piqued your interest!

Caroline A. Moody: www.forevermoody.com

Benoît Robitaille

Dr. Matt Lodder

Dr. Lars Krutak: www.larskrutak.com

Sarah Johnson: @tattoos_by_sarahj

Aaron Deter-Wolf

Tattoo Museum William Robinson: tattoomuseum.org

Stiftung Historische Museen Hamburg/Museum für Hamburgische Geschichte: www.hamburgmuseum.de

Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa: www.tepapa.govt.nz

Deno Tattoo: circustattoo.bigcartel.com

Claudia DeSabe: www.claudiadesabe.com

Jamie Jelinski

Marina Inoue: www.marinainoue.com

We’d also like to thank everyone who has volunteered their time to help make this launch a reality, especially our advisory board members.

story:
Who says saving the Republic can’t be fun?

You don’t want to miss the ultimate intellectual festival for freedom lovers! Especially with this workshop planned:

FreedomFest is convening again at Planet Hollywood in Las Vegas July 8 through 11, and it is looking amazing!

Even if you don’t count yourself as a member of the Libertarian movement (plenty of folks in our team don’t), you’ve got to see what this is all about.

Freedom Fest is not just an intellectual festival it is an intellectual feast!

Where else can you watch a debate between Steve Moore and Paul Krugman (too bad it isn’t a boxing match!).

Of course, another reason why I’m so excited is that Compact for America will have a huge presence at FreedomFest this year.

FEE President and Compact for America Board Member Larry Reed will be warming folks up with “What Alexis de Tocqueville Teaches Us about American Exceptionalism -- Can It Last?” at 5:05 p.m., Wednesday, July 8th!

CEO Chip DeMoss and Development Assistant Elisa Montealegre will be centrally positioned at Booth 324 to answer all of your questions (and tweet up the action)!

Then, on Friday, July 10th at 1:30 p.m., we’re sponsoring a fantastic debate over Article V, called “States Take Charge? Washington is Broken, Can the States Fix It?” The debate will feature Constitutional Scholars Bill Norton, Trent England, and Nick Dranias!

After the debate, you’ll be able to relax, enjoy a few beverages and snacks, and learn more (or just hang out) with CEO Chip DeMoss, VP Jeff Utsch, and Compact Commissioner Paulette Rakestraw (and the guy emailing you) at a Boulevard Suite we’ve reserved for private meetings and discussions!

Make sure to get the details at Booth 324.

And finally on Saturday, July 11th at 4:00 p.m., just before Sen. Mike Lee’s reception, we’re going to have a fantastic workshop event featuring Compact Commissioner Rakestraw, CFA VP Jeff Utsch, and CFAEF President Nick Dranias.

You’ll never have a better opportunity to learn why the Compact for America initiative is the most powerful, yet plausible movement afoot to reform Washington from the States!

Please join us!

But also please consider supporting this huge educational push! It will cost us nearly $20,000 in travel expenses, team compensation, and promotional costs to bring this educational opportunity to FreedomFest.

Anything you can do to help defray that cost will make it possible for us expand and repeat! 

Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Nadine Dorvelus, I was born and raised in Port-Au-Prince, Haiti, but have lived in New York for over 20 years. During the time that I lived in Haiti, much of the country’s population was under a state of poverty; this frequently occurred at the expense of the island’s children - parents often didn’t have enough food to feed their children or money to send them to school or provide adequate clothing or shelter. I grew up watching so many abandoned children roaming the streets during all hours of the day and night, in search of food, shelter and sometimes their parents. Some who consider themselves fortunate end up living with strangers who treat them as child slave. Before the devastating 2010 earthquake, 400,000 children, approximately 1 of 10, were living in an orphanage. After the earthquake struck, that number quickly doubled and added to the already urgent condition of children with nowhere to go. 

In 2012, I, along with a few close friends from Haiti, founded Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti, Inc. with the belief that every child, despite circumstances, deserves an opportunity to simply be a child - to laugh, play, run, grow and be happy. In 2014, we got approved as a 501(c)(3) organization, and Oceanie Orphanage moved a step closer to coming to fruition.

What We Need & What You Get

Our target is to raise at least $50,000 by November 30, 2015. This amount will support Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti in the following ways:

  • Purchase (or temporarily rent) a house and other accompanying expenses, including furniture, beds, tables, and chairs for about 10children;
  • Support the daily needs for our children including hygiene care, clothing, and food during the first few months of operations;
  • Establish an educational and training program for our children in our first year of operation; and
  • Support the general operations including wages for staff

100% of all funds donated to this campaign will be given to the Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti, Inc.. Full accounting of the funds donated will take place by the conclusion of the 2015 calendar year and will be published along with Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti’s yearly financials. All donations are tax-deductible.

The Impact

Our goal is to purchase a home or facility in an area in Haiti with less outreach than the areas that have received attention since 2012 and to house about 10 children by Spring 2016. We will use additional funds raised through this campaign to provide the children with food, education, clothing, medical care, etc.

Risks & Challenges

In the Haitian culture, there is a saying: piti, piti, swazo fè nich li, meaning that ‘little by little the bird builds its nest,’ the undertaking of Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti is no small feat, we realize this, but we are committed and ready for the challenge of changing the lives of Haitian children for generations to come until poverty is eradicated in our home country. There is a tremendous amount of work to be done, and with your help, building our nest, the Oceanie Orphanage of Haiti, will be possible! 

Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially. If you support our mission, you can still help in the following ways:

  • Make some noise about this campaign by sharing and re-posting our story
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • Keep updated on our progress through our website and Facebook page

story:
Lucky Lane is an independent non-profit, non-affiliated private preschool licensed by the state of Missouri. All of our incurred expenses and improvements to the school are paid by tuition, fundraisers, and annual giving events. The school is owned and operated by the Lucky Lane Association.


We are humbled by how many alumni choose to send their own children to Lucky Lane.
Says Carly Purdy, Director

Natural light illuminates this sweet Mid-Century postmodern school house that rests upon five gorgeous green acres boasting with natural wild life, four cool distinct playgrounds, wide playing fields, a music room, an extensive library, an indoor wheel room, a garden, and a beautiful picnic pavilion. 

Lucky Lane has nested securely off of Conway for 65 years establishing thick roots rich with history. This lucky little school has weathered decades in West County and is perfectly accessible due to the central location close to Highways 270 and 40 --which is right by many major hospitals and office campuses. 

The new board has a lot planned this year to commemorate the banner year including a 65th gala celebration. Lucky Lane is a special place where generations of St. Louis children have discovered much more than letters, number, and shapes. 

In the fifties, the county did not look like it does today. It was not as developed. The way the story goes, or at least how my mom always told it to me when I went here, Mrs. Morton May was driving around with her friends looking for a piece of land when they came upon a “lucky” lane that led them to a perfect rolling hill. Finding that spot was pure “luck.” Goldie Millstone and her husband purchased the land and then donated it to build a nursery school. Hence the name, Lucky Lane Nursery School.
Lisa Slawin Acree, Alumnae

#ILoveLuckyLane
If you would like more information about this topic, please contact Carly Purdy at 314-434-4462 or email at iloveluckylane@gmail.com.

story:
We are a great non-profit organization in New York City called Project Brownstone. The organization was founded in 2013. It is a community response to a crippling issue plaguing children of color throughout America– self esteem. Our aim is to find holistic ways of developing and empowering underserved youths, starting in Harlem.


The organization was founded, in part, based on the 2005 legislation that formed the Amistad Commission. The Commission is mandated to incorporate the African American experience into the history curriculum of the NYS public schools. This speaks directly to the issue of self-esteem.

The Textbook Stipend Project:

We developed the Textbook Stipend Project to supply textbooks and supplies to underserved students transitioning to college. The stipend is used as a tool to engage students in 360-degree development over their 4-year college experience with the intent of fostering leadership as well as entrepreneurship.

 Although we are sending a dozen students to school this fall, the organization still has a long waiting list. We can do more with your help.


The Amistad Watch:

Large percentages of inner-city youths have no grounding in the narrative that remotely explains how they arrived at the present. It doesn’t embrace them as part of the fabric of the American story. Project Brownstone’s Amistad Watch has been successful in working towards changing that experience. We partnered with the NYS Department of Education and succeeded in adding notes to the new Social Studies framework that was adopted by the NYS Board of Regents.

Although this has been a successful partnership, the organization still needs more support in reaching a wider audience in the political spectrum to make sure its hard work does not fall through the cracks.

Arts Programs:

Aside from our core programs, the organization has been successful in bringing arts to the community, as well. Last Fall, we premiered the Gallery Series, showcasing the work of a local artist. This year, we started the Poetry Open Mic Series, which brought together a lot of young talented poets. Next year, we are planning to have a documentary series, helping the youth go beyond expectations and gain hand-on training in all areas of music production. 


We Need You:

Of course, Project Brownstone cannot do this important work without the support of people like you. We appeal to you to make a donation, and to choose the organization as one of your charitable giving priorities.

Your funds will help us to pay our rent (20k), help us to pay our utilities, office supplies, office equipment (4k), and help us to have a little extra cash on hand for miscellaneous (1k).

story:
Fund 50 schoolchildren to get an awesome education at Awake and Shine school!

7 years ago, we began a journey that changed our lives.  During a village homestay in northeastern India (Samthar valley) - near the border of Nepal - we came upon an incredible school started by a retired General - General Jimmy Singh.

Over the past few years, we have watched the school grow from 30 children to our 100 children and have taken on the responsibility of adopting the tuition costs of 50 of those children.

We realized that to be able to sponsor the education of a child at this school is one of the meaningful things we could do in our lives.

Our kids (Omiya (aged 11) and Vyom (aged 9)) have been an integral part of this joy of helping others.

But we need your help to fulfill our dream...

We need to raise enough funds for our 50 children to complete their primary school education and move on to the next step of education in the nearby city - Kalimpong, West Bengal, India.

100% of your contribution goes to the children

100% of your contribution will go towards the tuition for these children.  The cost of education (tuition, school supplies) is $200 per year.  Each child will take 5 years to complete Upper Kindergarten (UKG) to Level 4 before having the opportunity to move to a school in city of Kalimpong 3 hours away.  This will then ensure they will be able to eventually reach their education goals and transform their lives.

Your contribution will change lives

When we first went to Samthar Valley and visited the Awake and Shine school (www.awakeandshine.org) we were blown away by the awesome education these children were receiving.  In contrast, the local government run schools were drab, very basic and depressing and a significant amount of the time, the teachers did not show up for teaching classes.  Please see the video taken by our daughter Omiya, then aged 7, of the shocking state of these schools.

Risks & Challenges

We have run a number of medical camps in the villages surrounding the school in the past 7 years since we first went there, but what we have realized is that education is the key to transforming the lives of the people.  

We are very fortunate to have the opportunity to have visited the school, watched the children grow and have trustworthy people such as the General Jimmy Singh and a volunteer teacher and prinicipal - Maureen Blake make sure our contribution actually equips the children with those essential skills.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this campaign - we are determined to make a difference with your help!

Every little donation counts.  If you feel that you cannot contribute to sponsoring a complete year of education, even sponsoring for part of a year will help tremendously.  We have seen first hand how these children have developed over the years and gone on to pursue dreams in and outside of their hometown.  We have seen how the Valley has changed with this school, and how the community has come together for the children.

story:
For a startup, this is the stuff dreams are made of...

Hi there!

Pelser and Lodewyk Uys here.  We are 2 very excited entrepreneurs from Gauteng, South Africa.

 My brother and I started making our dream a reality about 2 years ago when we launched our first web-based startup company called Notes&Crosses.

Notes&Crosses is an online platform where students can sell and buy study notes as well as get online tutoring.  Students looove the idea and we can see it making a real difference when studying for exams!

We have seen some steady growth and have been bootstrapping (funding the company from our own pockets, no easy feat!) the company for the last 24 months.  We recently entered and were interviewed by the "the best technology conference on the planet" (according to Forbes) called Websummit.  Much to our surprise and delight they invited us to exhibit our company at WebSummit 2015 happening in November 2015 in Dublin, Ireland! Seeing as they interviewed close to 25 000 startups and, in 2014, only 10 startups from Africa was invited, we see this as a massive opportunity! 

Websummit you might say, what is that? 

Basically, its where the Tech World meets.  Investors, inventors, startups and massive Fortune 500 companies (Google, Facebook etc.) from 130 different countries come together for 3 days of conversations, talks and pitching of ideas, all happening in Dublin Ireland. This is the place to meet investors, to rub shoulders with the giants of the tech world and to make connections like no other place on earth.

So imagine this - a small (yet growing) startup all the way from South Africa gets invited to exhibit their startup and showcase it to the world, we are over the moon!

What We Need & What You Get

Ok, so we get to exhibit for free and only need to pay a basic registration fee of 1950 Euro.  To put this in perspective - large companies such as Google etc pay 10950 Euros to exhibit at the same event!
What we get when registering:

The package contains:

  • Four tickets to Web Summit which include access to all three days (500+ speakers across 15 different stages, 100+ Partners, 500+ startups) and the Night Summit. (3 nights of of socialising, networking and building relationships across Dublin’s fair city) .

  • Exhibition space for one of the three days in your chosen industry area.

  • Startup Search Profile: Online circulation to investors, media & strategic partners. (this is a massive opportunity!)

  • Access to partner activations (workshops, roundtables, office hours etc).

  • Fulfilment officer to help with preparations and gather all your information 5 weeks out from the event.

  • Access to Web Summit networking app to help you build connections prior to the event & curate your own schedule. (Released 1 week before event).
If we don't reach our goal we will use the money to further develop and grow our product, a win-win situation!
We want to give you something in return - so why not give us a shopping list or wish list whilst we are in Ireland and we can get it for you?

The Impact

Our long term plan is to expand our startup into Europe and this would be the perfect platform to launch the business in Europe.  

Why did we start Notes&Crosses? Well - we feel that, for the average student, there must be an easier way to study and that the current academic model is outdated.  We offer a platform where students can make money by selling their notes and tutoring online and also a platform where the average student can actually buy study aid and study smarter and believe us, the students love this!

Risks & Challenges

We believe that we have a great product that could really add value to a students life.  The risks involved in going to the Summit is minimal, we know this is a massive opportunity and need to be there to grow our business.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to contribute but cannot at this stage - please share the campaign and get the Notes&Crosses word out, but if at all possible, please donate to this cause! 

Kind regards

Pelser and Lodewyk Uys

story:
INTRODUCTION

Namaskaram, 

We have a question for you. 

Solving or mitigating poverty is a huge task. Is it possible to really solve poverty with just a SUSTAINABLE model? A model that just keeps the organization's head above water with no room for growth?  This was our question two years ago when we set out on out mission to solve poverty using business principles. Why not solve poverty with a model that was SCALABLE? One that could grow from within and expand through the very people that it helped?  Armed with a bucket load of ambition, a pinch of crazy and two years of trial and error under our belt, we are finally ready launch that venture, that dream, that change.

This is not a side project or something that our team does part-time. We have committed heart and soul to successfully creating a venture that is capable of solving poverty at scale. I may not be able to change the world yet -- but I do want to change India. With your help, we will take our first step in launching a venture that we believe will solve poverty in India like never before.

What we need 

Our school focuses on helping slum and village students to transition into the professional work force and pull themselves out of their caste and poverty cycle. We have trained over 150 students in the last two years under the sustainable model. We have room to grow. To build our first official school and become the brand of helping in India we need to raise a minimum of $15,000. In addition to this amount, we have found a sponsor who has agreed to match every dollar donated to this campaign. The money raised in this campaign will go towards laying out the foundation for our school, a marketing budget, legal fee’s and compensation for our early employees.

What pain are we solving?

India graduates 6 million college students every year, of which only 3% are employable due to a lack of soft skills and English fluency. Low income families send their children to universities in hopes that they will develop the necessary skills to find quality employment and break free from generational poverty. Due to the lack of employment preparation that universities offer, millions of students return back to poverty even after getting a college education. 

What is our solution?

At KVM we bridge the gap between education and employability. We have created a state-of-the-art professional development program where impoverished students can engage in an intensive, two-month English immersion program that prepares them to face job interviews and ultimately find quality employment. 

Who do we help?

Our beneficiaries are graduated college students who are seeking employment. We deal with students from various backgrounds and majors, ranging from electrical engineering and math to teachers and IT support. All of our students are between ages 18-28 years old and come from families that aspire to see their children reach new levels of financial freedom.

How do we measure our success?

Our success will be measured by the percentage of students we are able to place in the workforce.We have already seen many of our students complete our program and gain jobs with salaries that exceed 10 times their parent’s current annual salary. This change in earning potential then allows our students to provide better educational opportunities for their children and thus break the cycle of poverty that pervades many of the uneducated that reside in slums and villages throughout India. 

Who is our network?

Our network and core location is centered in India for several reasons (predicted economic growth, service demand, etc.) Our network will consist of a) universities to draw students from and b) companies to place our students upon graduation from our program. The following are universities and influential people who are currently working closely with us: Gitam University, Andhra University, Aditya College. Santosh Nakaraboina (MA. Linguistics/English),  Satish Kumar (BA. Journalism), Surya Rao (Rotary Club Board Chairman).

Who is our team?

What have we done so far?

We have run KVM in India now for over 2 1/2 years. During that time we have:

·  Raised seed funds of $60,000

·  Graduated 105 students

·  Increased the English fluency of our students by 26%

·  Placed approx. 60% of our students in jobs making an average of 400% more than their parents annual income

How ELSE can you help?

Changing the lives of those less fortunate has been fulfilling and rewarding. We would be thrilled for you to join us for the ride. We appreciate the generosity and help that has been given and want to thank each of you personally and give some other perks as well. Some of the thank you gifts include, personal letters from our students and founders, beautiful Indian tapestries, naming classrooms after you or even naming an entire school after you! If we do not reach our goal, the funds will still help us to get off the ground and move our venture forward. We will figure out how to raise the rest on our own!

If finances are tight, we understand. We are always looking for talent for our team here in the US and even international interns in India. Shoot us an email with any ideas that you feel could help. Reaching out to friends that may be in a situation to help or even a share on your social media will go a long way!

Learn more about KVM Foundation Here.

story:
Short Summary

Baked goods, frozen pizza, and magazine subscriptions. What do all three of these things have in common? Answer: we all have some not-so-fond memories of selling one of these for a school fundraiser. As a result, we ended up with a freezer full of pizza and about three total sales to family members—not exactly the most effective fundraiser for the schools. 

The issue of school funding has been around since before most of us can remember but no one has taken the initiative to develop school fundraiser that not only works, but is also one that that students and parents actually want to participate in.

Until now...

WhatINeedforSchool.com is the first and only program of its kind where students, parents, educators, and businesses can work together to raise money for education and earn money for themselves at the same time! That's right, a school fundraiser where instead of receiving unneeded and unwanted rewards for all your hard work, you receive a check with your name on it to be spent on school fees, school supplies, extracurricular activities, or whatever you else you want.

My name is Erick Roflson and I came up with the idea for WhatINeedforSchool.com about three years ago. I am a husband and father of five so I know just as well as anyone that sending your kids to school is expensive. With this burden in mind, I began wondering, “How can I help solve the ongoing problem of school funding while helping myself, my family, and my community at the same time?” Finally it hit me. Students could sell a new and advanced savings program as a means of raising money for themselves and their school. Not only would we help raise money for education, but we would also help people save money daily.

In this savings program, the program will be available as an application on your smart phone—no more checking expiration dates or clipping coupons. All our deals will be as easy to access as sending a text message. Our savings program will consist of special deals submitted by both national and local businesses in your community. Every business that signs up will have the opportunity to advertise one standard deal good for one year for FREE! This generates more customers for business while branding them as proud supporters of students, their family's, & schools in the communities they serve.  We will also have two paid advertising programs where businesses can advertise a weekly special or a daily special or both! All of these deals will be pushed out to the users through our mobile application.

Every time someone signs up for our savings program, part of each purchase will go directly to the person who made the sale, part to the school they are supporting, and part to help our company continue to build and expand its capabilities.

But it doesn't end there. We are also in production of The School is Cool Foundation which will receive one dollar of every sale of our $25 savings program. We're setting up this foundation to help students overcome obstacles of adversity in their lives as they work to acquire an education. 

In short, EVERYONE wins!

After running a very successful beta test, we began development about a year ago and we now have a fully functioning website with every public school, private school, and college in the country entered in to our database. As our team builds and expands, we will introduce our mobile applications and continue to improve our website and expand our databases of schools to include the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, Germany, France, Sweden, Japan, Netherlands, Singapore, and throughout the rest of the world.

Our team, as of now, is small but growing quickly. The team started off with just me and an idea. I hired a team of developers to help get the idea off the ground. On a vacation in March, I met Dann, a communications major, and after his stellar Whitney Houston karaoke performance, I knew I needed Dann working with me on this project so I brought him on board. From there, we began recruiting passionate college interns from all fields to help get WhatINeedForSchool.com fully staffed. Currently the team is around twelve people and growing quickly.

WhatINeedforSchool.com is aiming to become a worldwide school funding solution. As of right now, we are nearly ready for our next step of introducing our program to everyone in America, but we need your help, Indiegogo. With your assistance, we will be able to finalize Phase 1 Development which includes finishing our Apple and Android apps and improving our platform so that it is easier for you to earn and save money. Of course, with your help, the sky is the limit!

As you can see, we have created our business model in a way that makes this a self-perpetuating idea. Everyone works together to benefit themselves and their schools. Businesses gain more customers and build a good brand by participating in our program and supporting education. Students, parents, and educators all earn money for themselves to use as they see fit. And, most importantly, schools will bring in loads of much needed funding.

Media Inquires:   media@whatineedforschool.com   



The Impact



Risks & Challenges

As everyone knows, starting a new business venture inherently comes with a load of risks. Although they do not always happen, the best plan of action is to be wary of these risks and have a plan to handle setbacks if they do arise. With that being said, we took a minute to kick back and think about what some of the risks that may stand in our way of helping schools worldwide solve their funding issues; here is what we came up with:

1. Fulfilling all of our rewards on time to thank all of you wonderful supporters is going to be one of our biggest challenges. We have to bring our team from all over the US together for the group dinners, deliver the Leap Pads to the sponsored schools, and be able to package and ship all our other rewards out to our supporters on time. With all this work and such a small team, we are facing some risk of not meeting our time deadlines. Rest assure that we will be working hard to get the job done.

2. Handling the expected influx of internship applications. Once we really get our word out, we expect many more students to want to get involved and join the team. So handling all of the applications, resumes, and hiring may be tough for our ten-person team. We believe the more that join the team the easier it will be to handle.

3. Making sure the server can handle everyone registering and that all the schools in the country can receive support. We have a HUGE server currently and increasing its size becomes easier with greater participation.

4. There is also a risk that the finalization of our apps for Apple and Android may also take longer than expected, which could be a timing risk. We are prepared to work around the clock to complete them.

Again, the unique thing about how our whole idea works is that it is set up to benefit EVERYONE involved. In this day and age, our society has a large and active support system that rises to the occasion when there are problems that affect greater good, such as funding for education. And, obviously, we all like to help ourselves and our loved ones. So this is where we all need to come together to empower a solution. At the end of the day, the only real risk is what are we going to worry about once the issue of school funding is finally solved?
story_txt:
Short Summary
Baked goods, frozen pizza, and magazine subscriptions. What do all three of these things have in common? Answer: we all have some not-so-fond memories of selling one of these for a school fundraiser. As a result, we ended up with a freezer full of pizza and about three total sales to family members—not exactly the most effective fundraiser for the schools. 
The issue of school funding has been around since before most of us can remember but no one has taken the initiative to develop school fundraiser that not only works, but is also one that that students and parents actually want to participate in.
Until now...
WhatINeedforSchool.com is the first and only program of its kind where students, parents, educators, and businesses can work together to raise money for education and earn money for themselves at the same time! That's right, a school fundraiser where instead of receiving unneeded and unwanted rewards for all your hard work, you receive a check with your name on it to be spent on school fees, school supplies, extracurricular activities, or whatever you else you want.
My name is Erick Roflson and I came up with the idea for WhatINeedforSchool.com about three years ago. I am a husband and father of five so I know just as well as anyone that sending your kids to school is expensive. With this burden in mind, I began wondering, “How can I help solve the ongoing problem of school funding while helping myself, my family, and my community at the same time?” Finally it hit me. Students could sell a new and advanced savings program as a means of raising money for themselves and their school. Not only would we help raise money for education, but we would also help people save money daily.
In this savings program, the program will be available as an application on your smart phone—no more checking expiration dates or clipping coupons. All our deals will be as easy to access as sending a text message. Our savings program will consist of special deals submitted by both national and local businesses in your community. Every business that signs up will have the opportunity to advertise one standard deal good for one year for FREE! This generates more customers for business while branding them as proud supporters of students, their family's, & schools in the communities they serve.  We will also have two paid advertising programs where businesses can advertise a weekly special or a daily special or both! All of these deals will be pushed out to the users through our mobile application.
Every time someone signs up for our savings program, part of each purchase will go directly to the person who made the sale, part to the school they are supporting, and part to help our company continue to build and expand its capabilities.
But it doesn't end there. We are also in production of The School is Cool Foundation which will receive one dollar of every sale of our $25 savings program. We're setting up this foundation to help students overcome obstacles of adversity in their lives as they work to acquire an education. 
In short, EVERYONE wins!
After running a very successful beta test, we began development about a year ago and we now have a fully functioning website with every public school, private school, and college in the country entered in to our database. As our team builds and expands, we will introduce our mobile applications and continue to improve our website and expand our databases of schools to include the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, Germany, France, Sweden, Japan, Netherlands, Singapore, and throughout the rest of the world.
Our team, as of now, is small but growing quickly. The team started off with just me and an idea. I hired a team of developers to help get the idea off the ground. On a vacation in March, I met Dann, a communications major, and after his stellar Whitney Houston karaoke performance, I knew I needed Dann working with me on this project so I brought him on board. From there, we began recruiting passionate college interns from all fields to help get WhatINeedForSchool.com fully staffed. Currently the team is around twelve people and growing quickly.
WhatINeedforSchool.com is aiming to become a worldwide school funding solution. As of right now, we are nearly ready for our next step of introducing our program to everyone in America, but we need your help, Indiegogo. With your assistance, we will be able to finalize Phase 1 Development which includes finishing our Apple and Android apps and improving our platform so that it is easier for you to earn and save money. Of course, with your help, the sky is the limit!
As you can see, we have created our business model in a way that makes this a self-perpetuating idea. Everyone works together to benefit themselves and their schools. Businesses gain more customers and build a good brand by participating in our program and supporting education. Students, parents, and educators all earn money for themselves to use as they see fit. And, most importantly, schools will bring in loads of much needed funding.
Media Inquires:   media@whatineedforschool.com   



The Impact

Risks & Challenges
As everyone knows, starting a new business venture inherently comes with a load of risks. Although they do not always happen, the best plan of action is to be wary of these risks and have a plan to handle setbacks if they do arise. With that being said, we took a minute to kick back and think about what some of the risks that may stand in our way of helping schools worldwide solve their funding issues; here is what we came up with:1. Fulfilling all of our rewards on time to thank all of you wonderful supporters is going to be one of our biggest challenges. We have to bring our team from all over the US together for the group dinners, deliver the Leap Pads to the sponsored schools, and be able to package and ship all our other rewards out to our supporters on time. With all this work and such a small team, we are facing some risk of not meeting our time deadlines. Rest assure that we will be working hard to get the job done.2. Handling the expected influx of internship applications. Once we really get our word out, we expect many more students to want to get involved and join the team. So handling all of the applications, resumes, and hiring may be tough for our ten-person team. We believe the more that join the team the easier it will be to handle.3. Making sure the server can handle everyone registering and that all the schools in the country can receive support. We have a HUGE server currently and increasing its size becomes easier with greater participation.4. There is also a risk that the finalization of our apps for Apple and Android may also take longer than expected, which could be a timing risk. We are prepared to work around the clock to complete them.Again, the unique thing about how our whole idea works is that it is set up to benefit EVERYONE involved. In this day and age, our society has a large and active support system that rises to the occasion when there are problems that affect greater good, such as funding for education. And, obviously, we all like to help ourselves and our loved ones. So this is where we all need to come together to empower a solution. At the end of the day, the only real risk is what are we going to worry about once the issue of school funding is finally solved?

story:
Bell & Bridge Crystal Foundation  is an NGO working with The World Health Organization (WHO) to roll out a National Strategy tool kit “TEENAGE PREGNANCY & THE GIRL CHILD ” to tackle the teen pregnancy issues in Nigeria.

In the aftermath of the “Bring Back Our Girls” global rally, we are also embarking on a project to create a National Toll free Helpline that will benefit missing children, rape and abuse Victims, and pregnant teenagers in Nigeria.

 

Teenage pregnancy is emerging as a pandemic in Nigeria and the lack of knowledge and awareness amongst teenagers and adults highlights the challenges to be faced in bringing this national strategy to fruition..



THE PROBLEM:

Thus far, the world Health Organization has successfully sponsored  awareness campaigns in 2 states in Nigeria. During these campaigns, we continuously receive complaints from these young victims, that they usually do not have anyone to talk to or have anywhere to go for help, hence the need for a National toll free help line as a first point of contact for guidance and support for victims.


WHAT WE NEED:

  • We need a toll free national helpline and center for pregnant teenagers, missing children, rape & abuse victims, where people can call to confidentially seek advise, guidance, or report a case for follow up with the police.
  • We would like to create a platform where teachers and parents can also call for information on how to deal with their teenager's situation.


All initial funds raised will be used to secure a building for a training center, computers, desks and telephones. Going forward, we will train volunteers to help us cater for a wider audience and ensure continuity of the initiative.


WHAT YOU GET:

We humbly offer our little perks  in form of OUR APPRECIATION, and  regular honor and recognition to you during our nation wide campaigns.

EVERY LITTLE AMOUNT WILL HELP US PLEASE


THANK YOU


OUR PAST AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS IN PICTURES

story:
ALLOW ME TO INTRODUCE MYSELF…

I am Marc Schulman, the prime content author of Poland: A Guide to Major Cities and Jewish Sites. Click this link to download our FREE Poland app for the iPhone and  here for the Android, to explore the beautiful, in-depth, guide we have created so far.

I have been teaching and writing about history for 30 years. I have also been an Apple developer for almost that long. I live in Tel Aviv and author a weekly column in Newsweek, entitled “Tel Aviv Diary”. 

I work extensively with my son Eytan, currently a high school senior and software developer. Eytan is a three-time recipient of the Apple Student Scholar Award, one of 300 students worldwide to receive that honor annually. At the behest of Moreshet, and with the support of the Polish government, we developed the initial Poland app together, two years ago.

This project is being sponsored by Mordechai Anielevich Memorial Holocaust Study and Research Center. Moreshet  was established by the HaShomer HaTzair Kibbutz movement in 1961 to commemorate Jewish organized resistance during World War II and the Holocaust. All donations to this campaign will be funded through American Friends of Moreshet, a recognized U.S. non-profit organization.

THE PROBLEM

Teaching history has always been my main passion and I have authored over a dozen history apps. Poland is where most of my family comes from, so learning about and exploring the history of Poland and its Jewish community has always been important to me. I have been concerned for some time about our responsibility to understand how we can honor the memory and secure the enduring lessons of the Holocaust after the last survivor and last perpetrator are gone.

OUR SOLUTION

I believe it is critical that we expand our existing Guide to Poland app to include the cities and towns that were home to Poland’s perished Jewish communities. Poland is rapidly changing, and while many of those places have been frozen in time, time is catching up with them. Our window for mapping the remnants of Polish Jewish life (including all of the cemeteries and buildings that were once part of Poland’s vibrant Jewish community) are rapidly closing. 

Poland is also a growing tourist destination, with Auschwitz being the singular most visited site. By providing the best and most comprehensive guide app on Poland, we will help define the narrative embraced by travelers to Poland, instead of leaving that mission to others. 

WHAT YOU CAN DO

By donating to this campaign you will help ensure that the story of the rest of Polish Jewry will be included in our Poland guide book app.

This funding campaign will allow our research and development team (including several members who live in Poland) to visit each of the towns and villages that once housed a Jewish community and to locate and photograph what remains of the Jewish cemeteries, as well as other Jewish communal buildings. 

We believe that if we reach the $20,000 goal, we will be able to include 95% of the cities and towns that made up Jewish Poland in our newly expanded app. If we do not reach our goal, we will still go ahead and expand the app, but we will only cover a modest percentage of the rest of Poland. In the event that we exceed our goal (which is our hope), we will extend the app to include neighboring countries, such as: Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and the Ukraine … AND we will upload the same information and photos included in the app onto a dedicated website.

In addition, as soon as the funds permit, we plan to translate our guidebook app into Polish, Spanish and Chinese.

story:
Short Summary

KettlePost was created as a response to the wastefulness of mail advertising. KettlePost believes there is tremendous value in advertising if done right.



Looking at the problem from a sustainability point of view: 
Click on the video to play.




We believe interacting with advertisement should be an enjoyable and rewarding experience without pressure, waste or interruption. We also believe that consumers, businesses and the governments around the world must actively confront the reckless consumption of paper and paper products, not just in advertising but also in everything else.


Another important aspect of KettlePost is its cash reward system. Advertisers can reward their viewers with cash incentives as a token of appreciation for their time and attention. People can choose the advertisements they would like to see, at their own convenience and they would get paid for doing that.

KettlePost's mission statement is:

a) Go paperless as much as you can
b) Empower people, start small aim big
c) Sharing is caring


Impact of Mail Advertisement



A quick look at the

User Experience DEMO


What We Need & What You Get


We need the support of the masses in all countries around the world. Whether you live in a large metropolitan area or in a rural town, you can support us both financially and by spreading the word about our campaign.

We are going to offer our desktop, mobile and TV applications for FREE without any subscription plans; therefore, our revenue will come later when people start spending the money they collected through our system. Like any other startup, we need to pay for office expenses, marketing and more importantly the salaries of our employees.

KettlePost will use the funds to attract talented people in software, design, and marketing. We can continue to improve our software, raise awareness and educate businesses regarding the benefits of paperless incentivized advertising using the funds we raise here. At the same time, apply for larger funds from venture capital investors who would definitely score us higher when we show them the support that you are giving us.

That's why you... are the power of the crowd!



Other Ways You Can Help


You can share our Indiegogo campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and elsewhere. Every small effort counts and could reach someone influential who would share our story with a larger audience and ultimately help us exceed our target.

Please explain our paperless initiative to everyone you know and ask them to support us. Help us reach millions of people in order to increase paperless supporters. Let's bring a positive change to the world.


KettlePost's Beta Testers


Since you are supporting us here, you should also visit our website at www.KettlePost.com and sign-up for our beta-testing. You will automatically be entered into a $250 gift card contest in which 10+10* contestant names will be randomly drawn as the winners.

* depending on which landing page you submit your info, you will be entered for a chance to win a "Nordstrom" or "Victoria Secret" gift card, where 10 of each are available to be awarded to contestants. See Rules on KettlePost homepage.

story:
Short Summary

Founded in 2009 by former Newport News Police Officer Bobby Kipper, the National Center for the Prevention of Community Violence (NCPCV) is working in communities across America to interrupt the process of violence, before it becomes an event.

By providing programs and solutions for students and adults of all ages, we are on a mission to improve the quality of life for all citizens.

Founder Bobby Kipper has extensive experience in the area of preventing youth and community violence nationwide. His background includes working on a number of key national initiatives with the White House, Congress, and the Department of Justice.

Since the organization’s inception, the NCPCV has developed a model bullying policy for the Virginia Department of Education (VDOE), as well as a Gun Safety Program for the Commonwealth of Virginia’s Board of Education. Both of these programs currently reach over 1.5 million students annually.

Barbells Against Bullies

What We Need & What You Get

FENTRESS CrossFit was our first gym that featured Barbells Against Bullies™.  It was an outstanding event! Over 100 men, women, and children came out to stand up against bullying. The National Center for the Prevention of Community Violence raised over $2000!

This year our goal is to raise at least $2500 before the actual event on March 28th! Even if you do not live in the Hampton Roads Area of Virginia, your contribution will help spread the program in other area schools.

Donate $30.00 and get a copy of "No Bullies: Solutions for Saving Our Children From Today's Bullies," by Bobby Kipper and Bud Ramey and published by Morgan James Publishing, New York.

The Impact

100% of the proceeds will be used to help bring bullying to an end through our GreenZone™ program.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in other ways you can help please visit our website www.solveviolence.com. We are actively seeking volunteers who share our mission philosophy of ending violence through solutions-based and community-driven programs. We welcome you to join us in this crucial mission.

story:
Urban Discovery Academy builds a brand new, brain-cell-popping discovery-inspiring, uber urban K-8 public charter school smack dab in the middle of the IDEA District of San Diego’s East Village. 

Is there a big need?

You bet. Big ideas need a lot of big, supportive backing. We are working toward our overall $750K goal and we're excited to be ready to put the last amazing touches on our new location.

Rooftop Pavilion

We need help in raising funds to finish the dream of our urban school with a safe, outdoor playground for our students. The almost 10,000sf will offer us a way to continue to deliver:

  • on-site playground
  • PE space
  • A rooftop garden
  • Middle school "cool zone" - outdoor classroom
  • and an iconic bell-tower

What's the BIG IDEA about having a school in the middle of the East Village?

Well, it's two fold:

#1 It's a huge idea for students & families

  • Our innovative new facility will offer best-of-class elementary and middle school including nearly 500 students.
  • Students will have the most dynamic campus both inside and outside its doors - the creative and innovative culture of San Diego's urban core.
  • Our students will benefit from the creative people and resources just blocks from our school.

#2 It's a mind-boggling good idea for the neighborhood

  • Our new facility will combine the renovation of an existing classic brick structure with new construction that is designed to be modern, architecturally distinctive. 
  • We will be open and thriving at least 12 hours each weekday and that translates to a vibrant, diverse, engaging place with lots of happy families visiting the neighborhood.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not help with a monetary donation please consider the following:
  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, share on facebook, pass along the info to those you think might be able to help.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much.

-The UDA Foundation

story:
Creating the Fallen Hero Memorial Chest Fund

When ShaKa Studios Custom Furniture was asked to make a memorial chest for the family of Army Specialist Mabry James Anders, we were honored.  We were also hesitant to charge the family full price, so we made the chest for the cost of the materials.

We know we can do better.

To that end, the FALLEN HERO MEMORIAL CHEST FUND, a 501c non-profit foundation is being created.  The sole purpose is to make solid cherry memorial chests for military families who have made the ultimate sacrifice.

Memorial Chests are used to store the uniform, medals, gear and flag of a fallen soldier, airman, marine, sailor, police officer or fire fighter.  The chests are bench-made from ethically sourced solid cherry lumber with eco-friendly finishes by ShaKa Studios, in the Greater Houston, Texas area.

The purpose of this Indiegogo Campaign is to raise money to launch the foundation and finish making the first three memorial chests.  The first three recipients are the families of Cpl Tyler S. Trovillion, 2nd Lt Peter H. Burks, and Sgt 1st Class Raymond J. Munden.


What We Need & What You Get

We have already started making the first three memorial chests.  The panels have been delivered to the engraver and the chests will be completed in a couple of weeks.  We have also hired an attorney to file the 501c paperwork.

We need $3600 to finish making and deliver the first three Fallen Hero Memorial Chests to their families. 

But that is not good enough.

InDemand Goal 1:  If we raise $4800 we can issue a refund to the family of SPC Mabry Anders who purchased the pictured chest. 

We want to do even more.

InDemand Goal 2:  We have been contacted by Tribute to Fallen Soldiers NW and asked to provide 12 Memorial Chests to Dallas-area families in May of 2015.  We need a total of $19,200 to do so.

The following video is from the 2011 Tribute to Fallen Soldiers Ride in Oregon.


You can help.

We are offering a broad range of perks in exchange for your contribution, ranging from a heart-felt greeting card to a selection of handcrafted furniture items from ShaKa Studios.  

As we reach our InDemand goals, more perks and sponsorship levels will be added.

The Impact

There is no doubt, that receiving a Fallen Hero Memorial Chest will be treasured gift for the family.  Once the 501c Non-Profit in is place, we can begin making and delivering even more memorial chests.  Our 12 month goal is to make and deliver 50 chests free of charge.  Our 3 year goal is 300 chests.


Risks & Challenges

With every endeavor there are risks, challenges and expenses.

There will be marketing costs to spread the word about this worthy cause.

If we do not meet our $3600 goal, 9% of the funds raised will go to Indiegogo.  If we DO meet our goal, Indiegogo gets 4%.  if you use PayPal, to make your contribution, we will also incur a PayPal processing fee. 

Perks need to be shipped, and so there will be shipping and delivery costs.  

Even non-profit organizations have costs of doing business.  Since the Fallen Hero Memorial Chest Fund will be making a product, there will be cost of goods expenses for lumber, hardware, finishing materials, delivery and labor.  While we gladly accept skilled volunteers to assist with the building of the chests, in order to guarantee top-notch quality, we will need to hire skilled craftsmen.  This means we will incur payroll expenses and be required to pay payroll taxes.  A working furniture shop also has overhead expenses like credit card processing, rent, electricity, water and trash.  Plus, professional fees to our attorney, CPA and bookkeeper. 

If we do not reach our $19,200 InDemand goal, we will not be able to make all 12 of the chests for Tribute to Fallen Soldiers NW in May.  If we do not, we will make as many as we can.  (More details about Tribute to Fallen Soliders NW will be available soon as a campaign update.)

We are open to receiving in-kind donations, for example lumber, materials, delivery services, free booth space at home shows or markets, or even perks for this campaign.  If in-kind donations are received this means we will be able to make even more memorial chests with the money raised.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help.  Use the social media share tools to spread the word about this worthy cause.

story:
In 1996 the Institute for Anarchist Studies (IAS) was founded to financially assist radical writers. We saw a need to assist the further development of anarchist and antiauthoritarian revolutionary thought. We sought to do this by providing grants to writers, so they could do things like take time off work and hire child care. The IAS supports people involved in social movements to reflect on their work, and to share their insights and ideas, in part by publishing their essays in our journal Perspectives on Anarchist Theory, as one of our Anarchist Interventions book titles, or by directing and assisting them to other publishers. 

Since 1996, the IAS has provided tens of thousands of dollars to over eighty people, including Jessica Lawless, Marina Sitrin, Matt Hern, Tamara Lynne, Kristin Herbeck, Eric Forman, Anne Yukie Watanabe, Dawn Paley, China Martens, Will Munger, Kristian Williams, and Theresa Warburton (to name a few). These folks and countless others have produced compelling and timely work, which has appeared in movement journals, books, and pamphlets.

The IAS is a volunteer organization, run collectively, with a paid, part-time administrator. We function through the mutual aid and generous support of people like yourself. We recently lost our non-profit status, and as we struggle to regain it, we really need your help.

One of our grantees, Eric Stanley, had this to say regarding our support, “Amidst the continuing collapse of support for researchers and writers, the IAS remains one of the last grant sources that directly funds people without institutional affiliation. Further, their dedication to expanding what constitutes the parameters of “anarchism” has helped proliferate anti-colonial, trans, queer, crip and otherwise disappeared tendencies in anti-authoritarian history and theory. With their support I was able to write "Fugitive Flesh," the introduction to Captive Genders: Trans Embodiment and the Prison Industrial Complex.”

Layne Mullett, who wrote “Brick by Brick: Toward a World Without Prisons,” had this to say, “Getting a grant from the Institute for Anarchist studies allowed me to carve out time to think through and put down on paper some of the lessons I've learned from years of doing anti-prison organizing. The patient, thoughtful engagement and assistance from my (IAS) grant adviser pushed me to move forward with a project I otherwise would have given up on and helped deepen my political thinking about the daily work of building a movement to end mass incarceration.”

In time, the IAS developed into other areas. We began to publish our in house journal, Perspectives on Anarchist Theory. We developed the Anarchist Interventions (AI) book series co-published with AK Press. We began to coordinate a speakers list and host tracks at conferences, organize the Renewing the Anarchist Tradition conferences, and most recently we have begun collaborating with AK Press on books outside of the AI series.

• For the last six years the IAS revitalized Perspectives on Anarchist Theory, with Justseeds artist Josh McPhee doing the cover design and layout. Recent themes have included Care, Strategy, and the Politics of Climate Change, with the next issue on Justice. The issue on Justice, currently in production, will feature essays by five people who have received IAS grants recently. These works address issues including a critique of the colonialist logic often deployed in community accountability initiatives; anarchist organizing around Hepatitis C and HIV; and former US military vets who have embraced anarchism as a result of their time in the military. In addition, Perspectives posts new essays on our website: http://anarchiststudies.org/2015/01/23/communit...

http://anarchiststudies.org/perspectives/

• In 2010 we launched our Anarchist Interventions book series with AK Press with Cindy Milstein’s Anarchism and Its Aspirations. In the last five years we have published five more books in the series, including titles by Harsha Walia, IAS board member Maia Ramnath, Andy Cornell, Anarchists Against the Wall, and Javier Sethness-Castro on subjects including the history of Movement for a New Society, undoing borders and immigrant freedom, climate change, Palestinian liberation, and decolonizing anarchism.

http://www.akpress.org/anarchistinterventions.html

• We are currently working with AK Press to publish the next two books by Walidah Imarisha, noted author, speaker and organizer. The first, Octavia’s Brood: Science Fiction Stories from Social Justice Movements, co-edited with adrienne brown, is a collection of essays. It is due out April 1st of this year. The second, Angels with Dirty Faces, focuses on the nuances and complexities of prison abolition, and will appear early in 2016.

http://www.akpress.org/octavia-s-brood.html

We need to raise $6,000 in order to award our annual writing grants in 2015, pay to print 1,000 copies of Perspectives, and financially support our part-time administrator to do things like wade through all the paperwork of restoring our 501(c)3 status.

To do all this, and more, we need your help! Please consider making a generous donation, and check out the list of perks available. As we approach out twentieth anniversary in 2016, please help to ensure that the Institute for Anarchist Studies continues to thrive! Thank you!

story:
What’s it all about?

We are Roam Cooperative, thanks for stopping by. We currently consist of three photographers: Jason Hales, Benjamin Brinker and Aaron Coury. We're going on a photography journey to Yosemite and we want you to come along!


Why Join Roam Cooperative?

Unlike many indiegogo campaigns we do not need funding to go on this trip; our trip is already paid in full.  We are offering you an opportunity to join our cooperative, experience Yosemite national park, learn photography tips and tricks, and connect with art you are proud to display.

We live in a time of overloaded instant gratification. Instagram, Facebook, Pinterest and numerous other social platforms feed us fresh content daily. As photographers, we take pride in creating unique and inspiring images that hopefully make you stop scrolling, even if only for a few seconds, to take in the beauty we've captured. 



This project is founded on the idea that photos are actually captured memories of a specific time that meant something and they are worth more than a few seconds of view. The three of us are already good friends, but we know this trip will deepen our friendship even more. Memories will be made and moments captured forever. 


You can go to many stores and galleries to buy photographic or many other forms of art. It may look great on your wall, but beyond that you have no real connection.  By joining roam cooperative you will get to get to know the photographers, watch us make your art, know why and how we made it, and know that you were the reason we made it. 




We want and are asking you to buy prints from our trip. As you follow our journey through our blog, facebook, and instagram,  the print or prints that you purchase will not only be created with you in mind, but they will have a story behind them.




We will be showcasing new art every day of our trip (february 22nd - march 1st, 2015), along with behind the scenes footage, and how to videos.  We want this experience to be interactive, so we will be answering questions and taking photo requests (within reason;) from co-op members.  At the end of our trip all cooperative members will be able to choose your art from a combined gallery of all three photographers. We believe in each other, so you won't know who took each photo. We are working together on this trip to create beautiful images for you.




Purchasing prints from this trip not only supports us as photographers, it proves that people still care about the preservation of tangible art.


How do you join roam cooperative?  Simple. Support our campaign.


Please Share!

Even though we've tried to make it possible for anyone to contribute, maybe you're just not able to financially support our campaign at this time. However, if you believe in us and this idea or happen to know anybody that is looking for some beautiful art, we humbly ask you to share our campaign on all your social media outlets. Indiegogo has made it easy with a few links to the left of the video or just click below. We would be very grateful. 
Instagram
Facebook
Website/Blog

story:
The Dino Community

Move over “Barney and Friends”.  Look out “Flintstones” and “Jetsons”!

      The Dino Community(TM) and DinoKids (TM) is a project that I have been working on for over 20 years.  This project brings lively fun stories, interesting facts, and engaging activities to children through dinosaurs.  The stories and songs contain positive messages combined, through fun, with science, sports and music; however, the "education" part is subtle.  Children will learn because the stories, songs and activities are all dinosaur-related, creative and interesting.

      Our NEW website will include online coloring books and posters, songs, games and science experiments.  All of the characters in the stories live in the Dino Community.  This is where they go to school, play sports, take music lessons, and join together for group activities.  The characters are engaging, positive role models who creatively resolve age-appropriate conflicts.
       You can view our former website here just to get an idea of the characters, stories and possible activities:
www.flutepianoguitar.com/dinokids/
        Please watch for updates, LIKE OUR PAGE and become a friend of The Dino Community:  www.facebook.com/thedinocommunity

About me:
My name is Dr.Kathleen Bondurant. I graduated as the youngest woman in the School of Arts and Sciences with a Ph.D. in Music Education and Music Performance from New York University.  Years ago when my step-children were young, they were really into dinosaurs and complained that there was nothing with dinosaurs on the internet or TV.  This was my inspiration for The Dino Community.  If you have children in your life, I am certain you would like to have trusted activities for them which do not include sex, sexual innuendo, or graphic violence.  This is just fun, imagination and learning about dinosaurs.

About my colleagues:
Attorney Lisa DeLong is Vice President of Legal Affairs, for contracts, etc...
Attorney Daniel Jochnowitz is our Intellectual Property consultant.
Andrew Morris is Vice President of Advertising and one of a very few certified Google ad specialists and he will be doing the marketing.
Patty Reeh is our Corporate Secretary.
Richard Dean Johnson is our game consultant.
Glen Gibson is our tax and business consultant.
DinoKids Enterprises, Inc. is a privately held corporation.

What We Need & What You Get

The Dino Community is ready to start out as a bilingual website with activities, stories, games and songs.
  • Funding is needed for web design to update the original website created in 1998 (which you can see at the end of this presentation) and artwork to illustrate the stories and activities. 
  • A few dollars will go to computer and software upgrades.  None of this money will be going toward salaries or remuneration of the officers.
  • Funding is needed to master the 8 existing songs and complete two more songs, plus production and marketing of the CD.
  •  We also need money for further development of the game and adding sound effects and music.  The game application already exists.
  • As a reward for having faith in this project, you will be entitled to a T-shirt, Tote bag, or the opportunity to name a Dino character.  Please see our "Perks List".   As this project grows, there will be many more "ground floor" opportunities offered to initial contributors. We always love to make new friends, too!
  • Funds will go to expand on the initial community and characters.  Should we not reach our goal, it will be disappointing, but several other avenues of funding, including an SBA loan are being pursued.

The Impact

This is a concept that parents and grandparents can trust, and have no doubts about it including questionable or morally unacceptable content.   Kids will be glued to the website learning about dinosaurs, following the stories and activities of the characters with new content created every week.

In my current test group of children, ages 6 to 12, it has been DEMANDED of me to continue writing as many stories and songs as fast as I can. 

"WHO is that?"  they want to know. . . "WHERE is Dinoville?"  

"Why didn't Billy Brachiosaurus make the basketball team in 'Hoop Hazards'?"

"What did Dixie-Dawn and the hamsterasauruses get for Christmas in the 'Christmas in Dinoville' story?"

I apologize if my descriptions seem vague or ambiguous, but I have already had several experiences with other people trying to take this project.   Having a fun dino-based bilingual project will revolutionize activities and bring more positive thinking to children.

    Risks & Challenges

    At age 24, I was CEO of a multi-million dollar business in New York.  Since then, I have created an award-winning arts program in Connecticut and produced Island-wide Music Festivals in the Bahamas.  I have great support with intelligent, experienced colleagues whom I have known for over 15 years and know I can trust and rely upon. 

          Personally, I have about $50,000 invested in this already, along with years of work.  My current "greatest challenge" is to get funding to finish the song album and produce it for marketing (2 more songs are needed about $8,000); have another generation of art rendered for the new website, album cover, story illustration, etc. (approx. $5,000); and then there is getting appropriate applications written for the dino game, so it can be online and cell. phone friendly.  We would like to get a short animation created for the website, too.

          We are a good group.  Trustworthy and hardworking individuals who believe in promoting better and fun content for children.  There is no doubt in my mind that we can overcome any obstacle.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We are taking resumes from artists and web designers, and are looking for a toy manufacturer.

      • Please spread the word and make some noise about The Dino Community.
      • Forward our Campaign to everyone in your address book!
      • https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/the-dino-community/ 
      • AND
      • www.facebook.com/thedinocommunity
      • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

      You just cannot go wrong with this!   And that's all there is to it.
